I was having the same issue with T-Mobile. I deleted the APN settings that automatically load when the network is found and manually added them back and my connection improved. Also, change the preferred settings from 4G to 3G. At 4G it is constantly looking for LTE. On 3G it will settle on HSPA+.
Posted via the Android Central App

I originally couldn't get data on 4G preferred connection with either APN I put in, so I dropped it to 3G preferred and got HSPA+ with terrible speeds of 2.5Mbps down. I then found out I should have the APN fast.t-mobile.com instead of fast.tmobile.com and it allows me to have the 4G preferred and get speeds around 15-25Mbps down. 
As for battery it's still too early to say, it seems pretty good in standby, but it looks like it may drain slightly fast with usage.

Edit: Just ran Antutu and scored 47682. I know that benchmarks aren't all they're cracked up to be though.

Re: the dual SIM
You can only have one data connection. It is this way on all dual SIM phones. The second SIM is 2g only - calls and text. MMS is sent over data, not the voice network, so that is why no MMS on the 2nd SIM.
Is wireless Qi charging an option with this phone?
I don't believe so, but it does have fast charging with the original charger.
Quantify, or any other owners, what's your battery life like?

Also worth noting that when on standby the aignal meter will say 3G, but when data is being used it will show your fastest connection.

thread.text:
Mrblueskys... you and I have the same taste in phones. We both have and love the HTC Desire EYE. So, let me tell you a bit about the zf2 in that context. 
Physically, the zf2 is only slightly larger than the EYE, but it's much heavier and doesn't feel quite as premium. They both share an oddly mushy yet hard to press power button. I have come to appreciate the rear mounted volume controls, however. The tap to wake and Zen motion gestures to launch applications are also really cool, but I've had to disable them because they occasionally launched while in my pocket. 
The software reminds me very much of sense in both function and logic. One of the brilliant things about sense is that it includes really useful upgrades to the stock android experience. ZenUI is like that, but even better, frankly. Sense does a great job with power management, showing which apps drained the battery over specific time periods. ZenUI goes much farther in both reporting and function, allowing the user to disable background usage and wake locks app by app, for example. I really find the entire ZenUI experience very polished and useful, and switching back to the EYE or my z3 compact seems like a downgrade. 
Performance on the zf2 is just beastly. While the EYE is certainly great and never left me wanting, the zf2 can multitask completely effortlessly, with no stuttering, pauses, redraws, or whatnot. Scrolling in chrome is perfectly smooth always. The camera launches immediately. Swiping on the keyboard never lags or decides to occasionally miss a trace. 
One of the reasons I love the EYE is for the rear camera. The selfie camera was never a draw for me... but the imx214 sensor, coupled with a two tone flash and fantastic camera software, is a great combination. The zf2 is actually better. Low light we know about. The real power of the zf2 camera is in software that is more powerful yet easier to use, combined with even better image processing. The first thing you have to do though is TURN OFF THE DAMN IMAGE OPTIMIZATION in camera settings. The stock settings make every picture look like an impressionist painting. Yecch. You may want to do manual optimization mode, and turn up saturation a smidge, but that's your call. 
Once that's done, you'll find the pictures to be excellent. Good colour, dynamic range, and well controlled noise. ZenUI expands on the excellent EYE experience in a few ways. The first is with useful image stabilization. This is followed with a neato ability to long press in the viewfinder and lock focus and exposure. Finally, the software is smart enough to recognize when HDR works be useful, and unobtrusively provide a direct link on the viewfinder. The HDR works very well, and the overlay shows few haloes and no loss of detail. 
Battery. Not great, probably not as good as the EYE, but I'm finding perfectly livable. The quick charge capability helps. No worse than my wife's Moto X 2nd gen. 
Hope that helps. Looking forward to your thoughts as well.
Posted via the Android Central App

I also won the ZF2 in the AC contest. I'm anxiously anticipating testing this device out. My excitement level is high especially after what you described Quantify.
:: hopes the device is on its way ::

Okay, a very quick comparison of different camera modes in low light from this morning, starring my very bored cat.
Scene 1: forced exposure to ISO 400. this is what the scene actually looked like. Image Optimization is off, Quality set to Fine
Other than my cat moving, not a bad shot. detail is good but noisy.
Scene 2: Owl Mode. Image Optimization is off, Quality set to fine.
Much brighter than the actual scene. Noise is surprisingly well controlled. ISO is not nearly as high as I would have expected (1160).
Scene 3: Auto Mode. Image Optimization is off, Quality set to fine.
I am impressed...very good detail and color, excellent exposure. ISO is only 1600. Owl model clearly trades off image resolution for noise, which is smart, but I'm pretty happy with Auto all around.
Scene 4: Auto Mode with Manual Optimization, Quality set to standard
So I used manual optimization, and went to 1.5 (out of 3) on the noise reduction slider. There are 5 other potential optimizations: Saturation, Sharpness, Contrast, Backlight, and Detail Enhancement. I left those at the neutral settings. Image Optimization probably uses all of these depending on the actual scene, but I wanted to test the noise reduction. 1.5 was clearly aggressive. I would have tried something else, but the cat decided it was time for breakfast and left the bed...

Wow! Thanks so much. 
Would you take some macro photos? How is the camera shutter responsiveness? Any lag taking photos?

OK, new cat pictures...Now with more light, AND comparison to Lumia 1020 and Sony Z3 Compact. Note this is a bit unfair, the Lumia has a 41MP sensor, and the Z3 Compact has a 21MP sensor. I didn't have my Desire EYE or Moto X 2014, which would have been closer, but we'll look at that later. Without further ado...all photos were taken without flash, and without zoom.
Lumia 1020:
What to say? this is where this camera shines...great dynamic range, great color. Still the standard, just tethered to 3 year old technology and a platform with a serious app gap (flamesuit ON). picture is too big to upload so you can see it here: http://1drv.ms/1y5r7hu
Z3 Compact - Google Camera, 20.7MP
This mode turns off most of the craptastic Sony image processing that kills what should be excellent images from a great sensor. Also good range and color...http://1drv.ms/1Fqm8Yx
Z3 Compact - 8MP Mode. Sony Image processing in all its glory.
Zenfone 2 - Image processing Off
Zenfone 2 - Full Auto. Yuck.
Zenfone 2 - slight noise reduction. I think this is probably the best compromise. Lots more fiddling to do. the nice part is, once you come up with a setting you like, it will stay until you change it...
Awesome comparo shots Quantify, thank you! Even though there are better.....the Zenfone camera looks to be no slouch!

My takeaway is that the camera is quite good. the colors are a little flat, but this again is adjustable in the settings to your taste. Camera speed is good, and the ability to lock exposure and focus with a long press is great. My only concern is that twice now, the phone has frozen while taking pictures. I'm sure this can be fixed with a software update, but annoying at the moment.

Thank you again! 
To you, does the scene with the cat on the bedspread look more like the Sony one, or the Asus one, color-wise?

Thank you Quantify, but: "Are that photos a little bit noisy?" :/
I'd like to buy the Zenfone 2 but i need to know if the camera is good or not. 
Thank you again.

title: ZenFone 2: Asus recommends 8 hr first charge

thread.text:
FYI - in the user manual for the 550ML and 551ML, Asus says to charge the phone for a full 8 hours before using it on battery power for the first time. I know hardly anyone does that and it's not like it is going to ruin your phone if you don't. But since the battery is not removable, I thought it was a good idea to let you guys who are concerned about optimal battery performance know this before you get your phones. 
There is no explanation given for it. I would assume it has to do with battery calibration after the battery has been in a low charge storage state but I'm only guessing. It's on page 15 of the manual, which I've previously posted here: http://forums.androidcentral.com/asu...er-manual.html

Don't most device manuals say something like that? I always figured it was more for liability rather than actual battery health. I'll probably charge it up to 100%, then for an additional hour or so afterwards.

replies.text: Most phones I've seen recommend a full charge. My current phone, a Note 3, just says to charge it fully before first use. This is the first I've seen that mentions an 8 hour charge. However, I don't collect phones - usually just have one at a time - so it's possible phones I haven't used before do. It was new to me. I'm used to removable batteries, which give you more leeway of course. I'm going to follow the rec on this one since it can't be replaced.

thread.text: Well I will give it a go and let it charge overnight and then hit up either Cricket or T-Mo for a pre-paid SIM so I can test it out without having to swap sims between the ZenFone 2 and my Galaxy S6 Edge. Just two more days for the Edge, and hopefully not long after that for the ZenFone 2, this will be a cool phone to play with for sure.
